DOC.HEAD: Mistrial in Drug Case Bush Cited in Speech; Jurors Can't Agree
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Thursday declared a mistrial after jurors failed to reach a verdict in the case of a teen-ager accused of selling the cocaine that President Bush used as a prop in a nationally televised address on drugs in September. U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin scheduled a new trial o begin Jan. 8 in the criminal case of Keith Jackson, who is accused of selling cocaine to an undercover agent in Lafayette Park across the street from the White House. Jackson, 18, also is accused of distributing crack at a mall and twice near a high school. The transactions allegedly took place starting last April 24 and ending Sept. 1 with the sale in Lafayette Park, ``We the jury cannot agree on any of the charges,'' the 12 jurors said in a note to Sporkin after four days of deliberations. In preparing for Bush's Sept. 5 speech about the war on drugs, White House aides decided to have the president hold up a bag of crack and arrangements were made to have a drug purchase near the White House. At Jackson's trial, his attorney, Charles Stow, brought out that a Drug Enforcement Administration agent at the scene of the Lafayette Park transaction wore a body microphone that didn't work. A camerman who was supposed to videotape the deal was unable to do so because he was assaulted by a homeless person, a fact which elicited laughter from the jurors. During the courtroom testimony, Sporkin observed that ``this is like a Keystone Kops thing.'' DEA officials have said they had difficulty getting Jackson to come to Lafayette Park because he didn't know where the White House was. In closing arguments, assistant U.S. attorney Mark Carroll said Stow ``has tried to nit-pick'' and said the four crack sales for which Jackson is accused did take place.
